frameDefinitions: An Entity has a particular scalar Attribute with a value exceeding a contextually-specified or generally-understood standard.
An Activity takes some Time_length to complete.
The LUs in this frame describe the level that a Rate, or the variation in some quantity over a period of time, deviates from the norm.
A Process of using or modifying is scheduled to be applied to a group or mass.
An event or state (here termed an Eventuality) or time-Period is described in terms of the Degree to which its duration diverges from a standard.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.
frameExamples: The <t>rapid</t> increase in obesity is a major cause of concern.
Three more cars <t>remain</t> to be fixed.
After a <t>lengthy</t> discussion with the Foreign Minister, Mr. Qian Qichen, they met the Prime Minister.
I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Entity</fen> for which a particular gradable <fen>Attribute</fen> is appropriate and under consideration.
The feature of an <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion.
A quantity or other characterization of the <fen>Entity</fen>'s state with respect to the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Value</fen> from the norm.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular <fen>Value</fen> for the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The event which requires some <fen>Time_length</fen> for completion.
The amount of time required for the <fen>Activity</fen>.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Time_length</fen> from the norm.
The individual who performs the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Activity</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Event</fen> whose <fen>Rate</fen> is being described.
The <fen>Rate</fen> at which something happens during an <fen>Event</fen>.
The activity that is being applied to the mass or the set of entities.
The mass or group that has not yet been processed.
The time when the <fen>Remainder</fen> is assessed.

A situation, action or event whose duration is being described.  The Eventuality occurs as the External Argument if the adjective is used predicatively, or as the modified noun if the adjective is used attributively: <fex name='Eventuality'>The lecture</fex> was <t>short</t>. We had a <t>lengthy</t> <fex name='Eventuality'>conversation</fex>.

Sometimes these adjectives describe simply a period of time, rather than an event or state.  The Period almost invariably occurs as the modified noun with an attributive adjective: We waited for only a <t>short</t> <fex name='Period'>time</fex>. Use of the drug over a <t>lengthy</t> <fex name='Period'>period</fex> can cause memory loss.
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.
listRoleExamples: Anthony marveled at the rapid <fex>rate</fex> of production.
An additional eighty-three invitations remain <fex>to be sent</fex>
In this case everyone should be informed by word of mouth to contact the person holding the list to find out <fex>which gifts</fex> still remain to be bought.
<fex>Now</fex> only three more items remain to be sold
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
